subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] can someone help me
msgSnippet: Given that the dialect uses post-vocalic r and a schwa for final I before n , it seem likely that it a variety of American English. -Andii
messageBody:
Given that the dialect uses post-vocalic 'r' and a schwa for final 'I'
before 'n', it seem likely that it a variety of American English.
-Andii

Jean-François Colson wrote:

>That's not in Read Alphabet (Quickscript) but in the Shavian alphabet.
>And that's already written in English, BTW.
>Here is a transcription in the IPA:
>
>lætətuːd ɪs fɔɹtiː-θɹiː diːgɹiːs ænd eɪtiːn pɔɪnt fɔːɹ naɪn θɹiː mɪnʌts. lɒnʤətuːd is eɪtiː-fɔːɹ
>diːgɹiːs ænd zɪɹəʊ eɪt pɔɪnt faɪv tuː tuː minʌts. pliːz dɒnt tɹæmpl ðɛ flaʊɜːɹs ɪn jɔːɹ sɛɹʧ fɔːɹ ðɛ
>kæʃ, ænd wətʧ aʊt fɔːɹ biːz.
>
>
>
>Which dialect is that?
>
>
>
>Jean-François Colson
>
>
